etymology.description: pictogram: cutting tool (knife/sickle); some ancient forms look like large scissors; original ‘mow/cut weed’ sense preserved in 刈; unrelated to 爻; cf. 辛
etymology.interpretation: Depicts a cutting implement, so meanings focus on cutting or trimming and extend metaphorically to governing or bringing order. Ancient forms resembling large scissors underscore the idea of clipping weeds to tidy the field. Despite visual similarity, it is not related to 爻.

examples.english: All under heaven is well governed and peaceful.

examples.chinese: 良臣能乂民(良臣能乂民)。
examples.english: A worthy minister can govern the people.

examples.chinese: 秋收时(秋收時)，农夫以镰刀乂草(農夫以鐮刀乂草)。
examples.pinyin: Qiūshōu shí, nóngfū yǐ liándāo yì cǎo.
examples.english: At harvest time, the farmer cuts the grass with a sickle.
